text: In a hybrid compliance uplift in medical devices where automation coverage is low and an audit is scheduled, what should the project manager do to recommend improvements based on quality gaps?

options.label: perform root cause analysis on defects before proposing fixes
accept the gaps to protect the schedule
hide defects so the team looks good
blame the team without offering corrective actions

explanation: Option a is correct because understanding causes leads to effective improvements. Option b is incorrect because tolerating gaps risks failure and rework. Option c is incorrect because concealing issues blocks real improvement. Option d is incorrect because blame alone does not resolve quality gaps.

text: Given a outsourced data platform in ecommerce where customers reported usability issues and a release cutover is near, which action best supports recommend improvements based on quality gaps?

options.label: change scope to avoid fixing defects
add peer reviews or testing where gaps appear
delay improvements until after go-live
accept the gaps to protect the schedule

explanation: Option b is correct because targeted controls address observed gaps. Option a is incorrect because scope changes should not replace quality fixes. Option c is incorrect because late fixes cost more and risk satisfaction. Option d is incorrect because tolerating gaps risks failure and rework.

text: While facing a agile mobile app in pharma where automation coverage is low and lead testers are new to the domain, what is the most effective next step to recommend improvements based on quality gaps?

options.label: hide defects so the team looks good
blame the team without offering corrective actions
train the team on quality standards that were missed
change scope to avoid fixing defects

explanation: Option c is correct because skill gaps often drive quality issues. Option a is incorrect because concealing issues blocks real improvement. Option b is incorrect because blame alone does not resolve quality gaps. Option d is incorrect because scope changes should not replace quality fixes.

text: For a agile billing system in defense where customers reported usability issues and lead testers are new to the domain, what should the project manager do first to recommend improvements based on quality gaps?

options.label: delay improvements until after go-live
accept the gaps to protect the schedule
hide defects so the team looks good
update processes and checklists to prevent recurrence

explanation: Option d is correct because process changes sustain improvements. Option a is incorrect because late fixes cost more and risk satisfaction. Option b is incorrect because tolerating gaps risks failure and rework. Option c is incorrect because concealing issues blocks real improvement.

text: In a vendor-led analytics product in defense where regulators expect evidence and production defects are escalating, what should the project manager do to recommend improvements based on quality gaps?

options.label: prioritize improvements by risk and impact
blame the team without offering corrective actions
change scope to avoid fixing defects
delay improvements until after go-live

explanation: Option a is correct because focus on the most critical quality gaps. Option b is incorrect because blame alone does not resolve quality gaps. Option c is incorrect because scope changes should not replace quality fixes. Option d is incorrect because late fixes cost more and risk satisfaction.
